Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Engineering Identity, its Predictors, and its Impact on Retention across Educational Stages

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports persistence in engineering by understanding how identity develops in high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, and how it may develop differently for underrepresented students. Identity refers to how people see themselves, or the "kind of person" that they identify with. Logically speaking, if individuals strongly identify themselves with a particular field, they are more likely to pursue and remain in that field. Yet there is limited research testing this idea, particularly in engineering. This project is surveying thousands of students in engineering programs at a variety of different high schools and colleges to build an evidence base. The results are being used to understand how engineering identity and early engineering experiences predict persistence to graduation and persistence in the profession. This information is being used to better design and evaluate the impact of early engineering outreach and interventions. The variety of schools and students in this study is enabling examination of differences by gender and ethnicity, which is informing interventions to broaden participation of underrepresented groups in engineering. The results are being disseminated widely to teachers, professors, administrators and others so that they can use the results to improve programs for engineering student recruitment and retention.

The investigators are employing survey scale development and multivariate regression modeling to examine the predictors of engineering identity and its impact on persistence at different educational stages. Identity is emerging as an attractive explanation for who persists in engineering, yet few studies have directly linked identity to persistence, nor thoroughly examined the host of factors that shape identity. This project is building on work on math and science identity, as well as research on the importance of professional experiences, to examine these issues. The study is unique in its examination of engineering identity across a range of educational stages, including high school, undergraduate, graduate, and recent bachelor's-level engineering graduates. Through ongoing longitudinal work and a cross-sectional design using multivariate regression, this study is describing engineering identity trajectories from high school through graduate study or professional employment. Study sites include 100 high schools enrolling approximately 5000 students per year in engineering courses and engineering departments of mechanical, civil and biomedical engineering at five institutions enrolling a total of 5000 undergraduate and 2000 graduate engineering students. The results are providing an understanding of how engineering identity develops and how that identity impacts persistence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to understand how engineering experiences, institutional characteristics, curriculum, and other factors influence engineering identity development and, in turn, students? decisions to pursue industry, academic, research, or other career paths in engineering. Understanding more about engineering identity, its predictors, and its impact on retention across educational stages informs improvements to engineering education, mentoring, and outreach efforts needed to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in engineering. Through this collaborative project with the University of Texas at Austin, we specifically focused on the factors that impact Hispanic/Latinx undergraduate students' engineering identity development.

Intellectual Merit: To explore this topic, we first developed a new scale for measuring affect toward key components of engineering practice. Because prior engineering identity research points to an interest in the profession as a predictor of engineering identity, our work sought to better describe this interest through developing a more nuanced scale. The six resulting factors are: framing and solving problems, design, project management, analysis, collaboration, and tinkering. During this scale development, it became clear that students do not necessarily view professional aspects of engineering practice the same as faculty and industry professionals do. To complement this scale, we also developed a new scale to measure engineering identity directly using a visual representation of the overlap between oneself and engineering via a Venn diagram-based scale adapted from psychology and management studies of identity. Together, these new measures improved our ability to model engineering identity formation, better than we could when using either scale alone.

To begin exploring factors that influence the engineering identity development of Latinx students, we compared differences in identity and its predictors of Latinx students at a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) and a Predominantly White Institution. Based on survey responses from 892 mechanical engineering students, we found that six of the nine factors analyzed (performance/competence, interest, recognition, analysis, framing and solving problems, and tinkering) were significant predictors of Latinx students' engineering identity, as were their institution, their gender, and having a parent with an engineering degree. Engineering identity was higher for Latinx students at the Hispanic Serving Institution.

Because of the potentially significant impact that attending an HSI had on Latinx students' engineering identity formation, we used a supplemental award to recruit a diverse set of seven additional HSIs to increase our dataset. In conducting a preliminary analysis of survey responses from students across the eight HSIs, no appreciable difference was detected in engineering identities of Latinx students across the institutions. This outcome was unexpected since the institutions differed concerning the percentage of Latinx students, course offerings, R1 status, and others. The final analysis of these results to explore the unique characteristics of HSI and their influence on engineering identity development via a cluster analysis is nearly complete. We also facilitated a meeting at UTEP with the HSI sub-awardees to explore the preliminary trends in the engineering identity development of Latinx students across our distinct institutions and explore opportunities for future collaboration. We are also exploring HSI students? sense of belonging in engineering and its relationship to their gender and racial/ethnic identity centrality.

In seeking to determine the impact that educational interventions have on engineering identity development, we compared the difference in students' engineering identity, engineering performance/competence, engineering interest, recognition in engineering, and affect towards the six professional engineering practices in two difference engineering departments at UTEP: a traditional program that implicitly supports engineering identity formation and a non-traditional program that explicitly supports engineering identity formation. Analysis of survey data from a total of 184 engineering students at UTEP (153 from the traditional and 31 from the non-traditional department) showed that engineering identity was higher for students in the traditional department than for students in the non-traditional department, despite the explicit identity development efforts. However, students in the non-traditional department showed statistically significantly higher levels of collaboration than the traditional department, a distinct learning goal of the non-traditional department. Therefore, we found some evidence that suggests that intentional identity development did not increase but could decrease engineering identity, perhaps due to competing identity formation efforts. Future work in this area exploring the impact on engineering pedagogy is warranted.

Broader Impacts: Ultimately, this work has helped bring to the attention of the engineering educational community, yet again, the critical role that minority-serving institutions play in educating a diverse engineering population. Further, it has helped bring additional insight into the myriad of factors that contribute to students' engineering identity development, particularly of Latinx students. In the course of collaborating on this project with UT Austin, this project introduced the PI and research team at UTEP to advanced statistical methods for instrument development and validation. Further, we were able to bring together a network of faculty from eight HSIs and, for several of them, introduce them to engineering education research for the first time.
